abstract.text: The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.

inlineContent.text: objects directly. Instead, you use objects that descend from
yourself and override its methods to implement the behavior you need. An instance of the
class (or one of its subclasses) is commonly known as a view object, or simply as a view.
Views handle the presentation and interaction with your app’s visible content. You arrange one or more views inside an

object, which acts as a wrapper for your content. A view object defines a rectangular region for drawing and receiving mouse events. Views handle other chores as well, including the dragging of icons and working with the
AppKit handles most of your app’s
management. Unless you’re implementing a concrete subclass of

or working intimately with the content of the view hierarchy at runtime, you don’t need to know much about this class’s interface. For any view, there are many methods that you can use as-is. The following methods are commonly used.
returns the location and size of the
returns the internal origin and size of the
object. (All subclasses must implement this method, but it’s rarely invoked explicitly.) An alternative to drawing is to update the layer directly using the
instances handle event and action messages, see
. For more information on displaying tooltips and contextual menus, see
is perhaps the most important class in AppKit when it comes to subclassing and inheritance. Most user-interface objects you see in a Cocoa application are objects that inherit from
. If you want to create an object that draws itself in a special way, or that responds to mouse clicks in a special way, you would create a custom subclass of
(or of a class that inherits from
is such a common and important procedure that several technical documents describe how to both draw in custom subclasses and respond to events in custom subclasses. See
directly and handle specific types of events, don’t call
in the implementations of your event-related methods. Views inherit their event-handling capabilities from their
parent class. The default behavior for responders is to pass events up the responder chain, which isn’t the behavior you typically want for a custom view. Therefore, don’t call
if your view implements any of the following methods and handles the event:
, presents the contextual menu. In macOS 10.7 and later, if the event is not handled,
passes the event up the responder chain. Because of these behaviorial changes, call
If your view descends from a class other than
to let the parent view handle any events that you don’t.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
An active area inside a control.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A stylized rectangular box with an optional title.
A mechanism for displaying text or images in a view object without the overhead of a full
subclass.
An object that clips a document view to a scroll view’s frame.
An ordered collection of data items displayed in a customizable layout.
A specialized view, such as a button or text field, that notifies your app of relevant events using the target-action design pattern.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
A container that aligns views in a flexible grid of rows and columns.
A view that displays OpenGL content in a view.
An interface that provides visual feedback to the user about the status of an ongoing task.
An abstract class that forms the basis of event and command processing in AppKit.
Informs the receiver that the user has pressed or released a modifier key (Shift, Control, and so on).
Informs the receiver that the user has pressed a key.
Informs the receiver that the user has released a key.
Informs the receiver that the user has pressed the left mouse button.
Informs the receiver that the user has moved the mouse with the left button pressed.
Informs the receiver that the cursor has entered a tracking rectangle.
Informs the receiver that the cursor has exited a tracking rectangle.
Informs the receiver that the mouse has moved.
Informs the receiver that the user has released the left mouse button.
Informs the receiver that the user has pressed a mouse button other than the left or right one.
Informs the receiver that the user has moved the mouse with a button other than the left or right button pressed.
Informs the receiver that the user has released a mouse button other than the left or right button.
Informs the receiver that the user has pressed the right mouse button.
Informs the receiver that the user has moved the mouse with the right button pressed.
Informs the receiver that the user has released the right mouse button.
Informs the receiver that the mouse’s scroll wheel has moved.
Informs the receiver that a tablet-point event has occurred.
Informs the receiver that a tablet-proximity event has occurred.
A ruler and the markers above or to the side of a scroll view’s document view.
A view that displays a portion of a document view and provides scroll bars that allow the user to move the document view within the scroll view.
A customizable item picker control for the Touch Bar.
An abstract base class for the views whose layout is managed by a scrubber.
A view that arranges two or more views in a linear stack running horizontally or vertically.
A view that arranges an array of views horizontally or vertically and updates their placement and sizing when the window size changes.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A multipage interface that displays one page at a time.
A reusable container view shown for a particular cell in a table view that uses rows for content.
An object that draws headers over a table view’s columns and handles mouse events in those headers.
The view shown for a row in a table view.
The most general programmatic interface for objects that manage text.
A view that represents the insertion indicator in text.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
Changes that cause aspects of a view to be invalid and require an update.
A manual provider of app entities that surfaces them to become
discoverable by the system the moment your view appears on screen.
The view’s bounds rectangle, which expresses its location and size in its own coordinate system.
Overridden by subclasses to draw the view’s image within the specified rectangle.
The view’s frame rectangle, which defines its position and size in its superview’s coordinate system.
Initializes a view using from data in the specified coder object.
Initializes and returns a newly allocated
object with a specified frame rectangle.
Overridden by subclasses to return a context-sensitive pop-up menu for a given mouse-down event.
A Boolean value that determines whether the view needs to be redrawn before being displayed.
Restores the view to an initial state so that it can be reused.
Updates the view’s content by modifying its underlying layer.
The view’s window object, if it is installed in a window.
A view that adds translucency and vibrancy effects to the views in your interface.
A window that an app displays on the screen.
Integrate Writing Tools support, including support for inline replacement
animations, to your custom text views on macOS.

doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/App.title: Adding Writing Tools support to a custom AppKit view

abstract.text: Manage the layer object that provides the view’s visual representation and accelerates drawing operations.
Respond to mouse, keyboard, touch, and tablet events and gestures that originate inside your view.
Specify the size and position your view relative to other nearby views using rules that update your view hierarchy automatically.
Change the view’s visibility, vibrancy, and focus ring and respond to appearance-related changes.
Review unsupported symbols and their replacements.
Draw the content of custom views and update that content when the view’s size or appearance changes.
Create a printable version of your view’s content and handle pagination and printer-related behaviors.
Manage contextual menus, cursors, tool tips, and other system-provided windows and content.
Adopt a simplified version of the Writing Tools experience in a custom
view using the pasteboard and macOS services.

doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/App.title: Supporting Writing Tools via the pasteboard

abstract.text: Manage the frame and bounds rectangles that determine the size and position of the view in the view hierarchy.
Manage the subviews, superview, and window of a view and respond to notifications when the view hierarchy changes.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that framework types adopt to enable you to provide content to system experiences.
A protocol that displays an instance as a live view in a playground.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
